doc.ContractDescription: THE MADDEN-JULIAN OSCILLATION (MJO) IS A PROMINENT MODE OF INTRA-SEASONAL VARIABILITY IN THE TROPICS. RECENT STUDIES HAVE INCREASINGLY VIEWED THE MJO AS A MOISTURE MODE , WHERE COLUMN-INTEGRATED MOISTURE IS THE CENTRAL PROGNOSTIC VARIABLE. THIS PLACES SOURCES AND SINKS OF COLUMN MOISTURE FRONT AND CENTER IN UNDERSTANDING MJO DYNAMICS. AT THE SAME TIME, ISOTOPIC COMPOSITIONS OF WATER HAVE LONG BEEN USED AS TRACERS OF MOISTURE SOURCES. CURRENT OBSERVATIONS FROM THE TROPOSPHERIC EMISSION SPECTROMETER (TES) INSTRUMENT ABOARD NASA'S AURA SATELLITE HAVE INDEED SHOWN THAT THE MJO SIGNIFICANTLY MODULATES THE ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION OF WATER VAPOR, THUS PROVIDING ADDITIONAL CONSTRAINTS ON THE WATER BUDGET. IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE WILL ADD THE REPRESENTATION OF THE PHYSICS OF WATER ISOTOPES (WHICH ARE AFFECTED BY MICROPHYSICAL TRANSFORMATIONS INVOLVING TRANSITIONS BETWEEN WATER VAPOR AND LIQUID OR ICE HYDROMETEORS, SUCH AS RAIN OR SNOW) TO TWO MODELING FRAMEWORKS: A FLEXIBLE REGIONAL NON-HYDROSTATIC MODEL (NU-WRF) AND A STATE-OF-THE-ART GCM (THE SPCAM), WHICH WILL SHARE THE SAME ISOTOPE MICROPHYSICS MODULE THAT WILL BE BASED ON ONE DEVELOPED DURING A PREVIOUS NASA PROJECT. THE ABILITY OF THE DIFFERENT MODELING FRAMEWORKS TO REPRODUCE THE OBSERVED PROPERTIES OF THE MJO WILL BE EVALUATED USING SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS OF WATER VAPOR ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION FROM TES, LATENT HEATING AND PRECIPITATION INTENSITY PROFILES FROM TRMM AND CLOUD PROPERTIES FROM CLOUDSAT AND ISCCP. THE ISOTOPE-ENABLED MODELS WILL ALLOW US TO BETTER INTERPRET THE OBSERVED MJO MODULATIONS OF ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION OF WATER VAPOR, AS WELL AS TO EXPLORE HOW CURRENT (AND FUTURE) ISOTOPIC OBSERVATIONS CAN CONSTRAIN THE MOISTURE SOURCES AND SINKS ASSOCIATED WITH THE MJO AND THEIR REPRESENTATIONS IN THE MODELS. AS THE SPCAM IS AMONG THE FEW GCMS THAT CAN SIMULATE THE MJO REALISTICALLY, THE ISOTOPE-ENABLED SPCAM WILL PROVIDE A BENCHMARK FOR THE NU-WRF. A MODULAR SIMULATOR THAT APPROXIMATES THE ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION THAT WOULD BE OBSERVED BY TES GIVEN THE MODEL PROFILES OF WATER VAPOR AND ITS ISOTOPOLOGUES UNDER DIFFERENT CLOUD CONDITIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED AS PART OF THE PROJECT.
doc.MajorAgency: STUDY OF THE MADDEN-JULIAN OSCILLATION WITH ISOTOP
doc.MajorFundingAgency: STUDY OF THE MADDEN-JULIAN OSCILLATION WITH ISOTOP

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE A SPACE TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATION OF MICROGRAVITY LOCOMOTION IN PERIODIC FRAMEWORKS USING MOJO: THE MULTI ORTHOGONAL JAUNTING ROBOT, A ROBOTIC SYSTEM SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO TRAVERSE AND INSPECT A REVERSIBLY ASSEMBLED DIGITAL CELLULAR SOLID. WE WILL ASSESS THE IMPACT THAT MICROGRAVITY HAS ON THE ENERGY CONSUMPTION, RELIABILITY, AND MAXIMUM TRAVERSAL SPEED OF THE ROBOT,AND EXPLORE WHAT SPECIFIC ADAPTATIONS CAN BE MADE TO THE ROBOT THAT IMPROVE ITS PERFORMANCE IN THIS ENVIRONMENT. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD CONTRIBUTE TO THE AUTOMATED ASSEMBLY OF LARGE SPACE STRUCTURE, A KEY MILESTONE IN NASAS ROADMAP FOR SPACE TECHNOLOGY, ENABLING LIGHTWEIGHT, MULTIFUNCTIONAL MATERIALS WHOSE FINAL SIZE CAN FAR EXCEED THE ENVELOPE OF THE LAUNCH VEHICLE IN WHICH IT WAS LAUNCHED.

doc.ContractDescription: MOTOROLA CHARGER

DEFORESTATION AND FOREST DEGRADATION OF TROPICAL VEGETATION ACCOUNT FOR 6 -17% OF GLOBAL ANNUAL CO2 EMISSIONS TO THE ATMOSPHERE (VAN DER WERF ET AL. 2009). INTERNATIONAL POLICY MECHANISMS DESIGNED TO ADDRESS EMISSIONS FROM FOREST LOSS SUCH AS REDD+ REQUIRE THE ABILITY TO MONITOR NOT ONLY EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION BUT ALSO FROM FOREST DEGRADATION AS WELL AS THE UPTAKE BY VEGETATION. WHILE MUCH PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN MONITORING CHANGES IN FOREST AREA AND CARBON DENSITY, MEASUREMENTS OF BIOMASS LOSS DUE TO DEFORESTATION AND DEGRADATION, AND INCREASES DUE TO UPTAKE REMAIN CHALLENGING. HERE WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A NOVEL METHODOLOGY TO MONITOR CO2 FLUXES TO THE ATMOSPHERE FROM LOSSES (DUE TO DEFORESTATION AND DEGRADATION) AND GAINS (FROM VEGETATION UPTAKE) FOR THE AMAZON BASIN. THE APPROACH IS BASED ON A COMBINATION OF THE INSAR TANDEM-X SPACEBORNE INTERFEROMETER, MODIS, LIDAR AND FIELD MEASUREMENTS. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT REQUIRED FOR A MULTI-SENSOR, MULTI-SPATIAL RESOLUTION MONITORING SYSTEM INTEGRATED WITH A CARBON BOOKKEEPING MODEL TO QUANTIFY CO2 FLUXES TO THE ATMOSPHERE FROM LAND CARBON DYNAMICS. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) QUANTIFY THE CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN TANDEM-X PHASE HEIGHT AND BIOMASS AND DERIVE BIOMASS CHANGES AS A FUNCTION OF PHASE HEIGHT VARIATIONS. USING TANDEM-X DATA TAKEN MONTHLY AND AT 50-M RESOLUTION OVER TAPAJOS FOREST BETWEEN 2011 AND 2016, WE WILL THEN DETERMINE THE ACCURACY WITH WHICH MULTI-TEMPORAL TANDEM-X OBSERVATIONS CAN BE USED TO MEASURE BIOMASS CHANGES (LOSSES AND GAINS). TO DO THIS WE WILL USE EXISTING FIELD DATA AND LIDAR MEASUREMENTS COLLECTED IN THE REGION; 2) ASSESS THE WITHIN-PIXEL SENSITIVITY OF MODIS DERIVED BIOMASS CHANGES. WE WILL BUILD ON BACCINI ET AL. (2012; IN REVIEW) AND DERIVE ANNUAL BIOMASS CHANGE ESTIMATES. WE WILL THEN COMPARE WITH HIGH RESOLUTION CHANGE ESTIMATES FROM TANDEM-X AND ASSESS THE SENSITIVITY OF MODIS TO SUB-PIXEL CHANGES IN BIOMASS; 3) ADDRESS THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT REQUIRED TO COMBINE INSAR SPACEBORNE OBSERVATIONS WITH MODIS REFLECTANCE. BY COMBINING TIME SERIES OF INSAR AND MODIS OBSERVATIONS WE EXPECT TO INCREASE THE SENSITIVITY IN BIOMASS CHANGE WHILE EXPANDING OUR MONITORING CAPABILITY OVER LARGER AREA; 4) ASSESS THE IMPACT OF DIFFERING RESOLUTIONS AND ACCURACIES IN BIOMASS CHANGE ESTIMATES WHEN PRODUCTS FROM OBJECTIVES (1) AND (3) ARE USED IN A BOOKKEEPING MODEL TO DERIVE CO2 FLUXES.

U-2 OPTICS SUPPORT AND SUSTAINMENT.

WE PROPOSE A THREE-YEAR PROGRAM OF RESEARCH TO USE OMI MEASUREMENTS OF FORMALDEHYDE (HCHO) AND GLYOXAL (CHOCHO) TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE OF EMISSIONS OF NONMETHANE VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (NMVOCS) AND THEIR TRENDS. NMVOCS ARE OF ATMOSPHERIC IMPORTANCE AS PRECURSORS OF TROPOSPHERIC OZONE AND OF SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOL (SOA). THEY ALSO AFFECT THE CONCENTRATION OF THE OH RADICAL (THE MAIN TROPOSPHERIC OXIDANT). WE WILL FOCUS ON THREE ACTIVITIES: (1) INTERPRETATION OF OMI HCHO DATA OVER AFRICA TO DETERMINE THE FACTORS CONTROLLING THE EMISSION OF ISOPRENE (THE PRINCIPAL BIOGENIC NMVOC) IN DIFFERENT AFRICAN REGIONS, THE IMPLICATIONS FOR TROPOSPHERIC OZONE (USING OMI AND TES OBSERVATIONS) AND AEROSOLS (USING MODIS AND MISR OBSERVATIONS), AND INCLUDING INTERPRETATION OF THE 1995-PRESENT HCHO TREND FROM THE SATELLITE RECORD (GOME, SCIAMACHY, OMI, GOME-2). (2) DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF ANTHROPOGENIC NMVOC EMISSIONS IN NORTH AMERICA FROM URBAN AND POINT SOURCES (E.G., OIL/GAS PRODUCTION) BY OVERSAMPLING THE OMI HCHO DATA, AND ANALYSIS OF LONG-TERM TRENDS OF THESE EMISSIONS BY OVERSAMPLING THE 1995-PRESENT RECORD OF HCHO SATELLITE DATA. (3) EVALUATION AND ANALYSIS OF A NEW OMI CHOCHO PRODUCT, AND CONSTRUCTION OF GLOBAL OMI CHOCHO-HCHO CORRELATION STATISTICS, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE COMPLEMENTARY VALUE OF CHOCHO AND HCHO SATELLITE DATA FOR CONSTRAINING NMVOC EMISSIONS.
doc.MajorAgency: USE OF OMI FORMALDEHYDE (HCHO) AND GLYOXAL (CHOCHO

doc.ContractDescription: A TEAM OF OCEANOGRAPHERS AND GLACIOLOGISTS PROPOSE TO LEVERAGE KEY NASA ASSETS TO VASTLY IMPROVE THE SCIENCE OF GREENLAND ICE SHEET (GRIS) MASS CHANGES. THE WORK CONSISTS OF CONNECTING OBSERVATIONS AND MODELING OF THE LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION TO THE DETAILED PROCESSES AT THE ICE SHEET-OCEAN INTERFACE. AT THE HEART OF THE MODELING ARE THE MIT OCEAN GENERAL CIRCULATION MODEL (MITGCM), JPL&UCI'S ICE SHEET SYSTEM MODEL (ISSM), AND THE STATE ESTIMATION INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPED BY THE NASA-FUNDED "ESTIMATING THE CIRCULATION AND CLIMATE OF THE OCEAN" (ECCO) CONSORTIUM. VARIOUS SATELLITE DATA ALREADY USED IN ECCO AND ISSM, NEW DATA BECOMING AVAILABLE THROUGH NASA'S OPERATION ICEBRIDGE, TOGETHER WITH DEDICATED IN-SITU OBSERVATIONS NEAR GREENLAND WILL BE USED FOR AN IMPROVED SYNTHESIS, AND WILL BE LINKED TO DETAILED PROCESS STUDIES. THE FOLLOWING COMPONENTS ARE BEING PROPOSED: 1. LARGE-SCALE MODEL-DATA SYNTHESES OF THE ARCTIC OCEAN AND SUBPOLAR GYRE THAT ARE BEING DEVELOPED WITHIN ECCO SERVE AS A BASELINE TO ASSESS DECADAL VARIABILITY OF GREENLAND-BOUND SOURCE WATERS; EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON ASSESSING THE SKILL OF THE ESTIMATES IN TERMS OF RESIDUAL MISFITS TO SATELLITE AND IN-SITU (PRESENT AND HISTORICAL) OBSERVATIONS NEAR THE GRIS. 2. ENHANCED RESOLUTION IS REQUIRED TO RESOLVE KEY PROCESSES ON THE CONTINENTAL SHELF AND IN KEY FJORDS WHERE MAJOR GLACIERS ARE IN CONTACT WITH OCEAN WATERS; WE WILL CONDUCT AN UNPRECEDENTED 2 KM HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION CIRCUM-GREENLAND OCEAN-SEA ICE SIMULATION WHICH WILL SERVE AS BOUNDARY CONDITION FOR COUPLING THE LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION WITH THE SHELF AND FJORD-SCALE CIRCULATION. 3. ATMOSPHERIC REANALYSIS PRODUCTS PROVIDE BEST ESTIMATES OF THE METEOROLOGY BUT LACK THE RESOLUTION AND FIDELITY THAT ARE TARGETED NEAR THE MARINE MARGIN. EXISTING PRODUCTS FROM GLOBAL AND REGIONAL PROJECTS WILL BE ANALYZED IN TERMS FIDELITY AT LOCAL SCALES. WE WILL INVESTIGATE WHETHER THE APPARENT ATMOSPHERIC VARIABILITY CAN BE RELATED TO OBSERVED FJORD-SHELF VARIABILITY, AND TO OBSERVED GLACIER FLOW SPEED AND THINNING. 4. PROCESS STUDIES ARE PROPOSED FOR TWO GLACIER/FJORD SYSTEMS IN EAST GREENLAND, 79NORTH GLACIER/FJORD AND HELHEIM GLACIER/SERMILIK FJORD, WHICH COVER A VARIETY OF RELEVANT CHARACTERISTICS (LARGE DRAINAGE BASINS; VERTICAL VERSUS SLANTED OCEAN-ICE INTERFACE; LARGE VERSUS SMALL BASAL RUNOFF). THE USE OF HYDROGRAPHIC AND, WHERE POSSIBLE, REMOTE SENSING OBSERVATIONS WILL PROVIDE A QUANTITATIVE BASIS FOR LINKING LOCAL PROCESSES TO LARGE-SCALE CIRCULATION CHANGES. 5. BASED ON CIRCUM-GREENLAND-FORCED FJORD SIMULATIONS AND MELT RATE ESTIMATES, TRANSIENT ISSM SIMULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED TO ASSESS IMPLICATIONS FOR ICE SHEET CHANGES. SEVERAL CRITICAL ISSM IMPROVEMENTS WILL IMPLEMENTED, INCLUDING CALVING FRONT DYNAMICS. SENSITIVITY CALCULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED IN CONJUNCTION WITH DATA COLLECED AT THE TWO PROCESS REGIONS TO ASSESS DYNAMIC THINNING AND GLACIER FRONT RETREAT IN RESPONSE TO LARGE-SCALE OCEANIC AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY. 6. THE AVAILABLE DATA, IMPROVED MODEL-DATA SYNTHESIS, AND ATMOSPHERIC FIELDS WILL BE USED IN CONJUNCTION TO TEST THE DECADAL PROGRESSION OF REGIONAL WARMING, ICE-OCEAN MELTING, AND MASS LOSS. IMPROVED ICEBRIDGE FJORD BATHYMETRY, SATELLITE AND GPS MEASUREMENTS OF THE GLACIER TERMINI, TOGETHER WITH ICE-OCEAN BOUNDARY CONDITIONS SHOULD HELP TO VASTLY IMPROVE THE SIMULATED ICE FLOW CHANGES OF OUTLET GLACIERS IN RESPONSE TO PERTURBATIONS. THE IMPACT OF ABOVE OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC PROCESSES ON GRIS WILL BE STUDIED USING THE ISSM. SENSITIVITY EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN ORDER TO STUDY LINKAGES BETWEEN OPEN-OCEAN, FJORD CIRCULATION, ATMOSPHERIC PROCESSES, AND CHANGES ON THE ICE SHEET. THESE SENSITIVITY EXPERIMENTS WILL BE USED TO QUANTIFY WHAT NEEDS TO BE MEASURED AND WITH WHAT ACCURACY IN ORDER TO MAKE IMPROVED STATEMENTS ABOUT ONGOING AND FUTURE ICE SHEET EVOLUTION SCENARIOS.
doc.MajorAgency: LINKING GREENLAND ICE SHEET MASS LOSS TO DECADAL C
doc.MajorFundingAgency: LINKING GREENLAND ICE SHEET MASS LOSS TO DECADAL C

doc.ContractDescription: IN-VIVO XTREME II SYSTEM WITH MARS

THE NUETRON STAR COMPOSITION EXPLORER (NICER) DETECTOR SUBSYSTEM DELIVERED TO NASA UNDER THIS CONTRACT CONSISTS PRIMARILY OF THE FOLLOWING ELEMENTS: FLIGHT QUALIFIED SILICON DRIFT DETECTOR FOCAL PLANE MODULE ASSEMBLIES (FPM). FLIGHT QUALIFIED MEASUREMENT AND POWER UNITS (MPU) WITH ONBOARD, QUALIFIED FLIGHT SOFTWARE. FLIGHT QUALIFIED FPM TO MPU FLIGHT HARNESSES. GROUND SUPPORT EQUIPMENT (GSE). MPU SIMULATOR. A SUBSET OF THE DETECTOR GROUND BASED CALIBRATION PRODUCTS. GENERAL DATA REQUIREMENT PRODUCTS CALLED OUT UNDER THE CONTRACT. THE NICER DETECTOR SUBSYSTEM PROJECT AT MKI IS MANAGED IN PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) MODE WITH THE PI RESPONSIBLE FOR DELIVERING THE FLIGHT HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, CALIBRATION PRODUCTS AND DATA PRODUCTS TO THE NICER PROJECT OFFICE AT GSFC. THE PI WILL DELEGATE TECHNICAL AND PROGRAMMATIC ELEMENTS TO APPROPRIATE MEMBERS OF THE MKI NICER TEAM, WHO WILL BE THE DAY-TO-DAY POCS FOR THE GSFC NICER PROJECT OFFICE.

SPARE PARTS (US) (UK) BASIC ORDERING AGREEMENT FOR OPERATIONAL AND ENGINEERING SUPPORT SERVICES, EQUIPMENT, AND SPARE PARTS FOR THE TRIDENT II STRATEGIC WEAPONS SYSTEM, FIRE CONTROL SUBSYSTEM (FCS), AND ATTACK WEAPONS CONTROL SYSTEM (AWCS).
